moves.1. g3 e6 2. Bg2 d5: This is an unusual opening by White, but not a bad one.  The idea over time is to give scope to the B on the long diagonal.
moves.3. d3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Nbd7 5. O-O Be7 6. Nc3: White would like to play e4, while Black would love to prevent it--or keep it from being a problem.
moves.6... c6 7. e4 O-O 8. Ne1: I was unsure of White's reason for this move.  But the wasted tempo gives Black the chance to gain space.
moves.8... d4 9. Ne2 e5 10. f4: White, correctly I think, strikes back immediately at e5, but this does leave White with some weak squares.
moves.10... Bd6 11. f5: I was a little surprised that White would want to lock into this pawn chain, which completely devalues the B on the long diagonal.
moves.11... h6: White's dark square B is a good piece, but has few good squares at the moment.
moves.12. g4: This makes White's K more vulnerable.
moves.12... Nxg4 13. Nxd4 Nxh2 14. Nxc6 bxc6 1: Material is even, but White's K is quite exposed.
moves.15... Qh4+ 16. Kg1: This is a mistake.  Bh3, ugly as it is, is better here.
moves.16... Bc5+: Now White will lose significant material and resigned here.  White was hoping, I think, to create a Kingside attack against Black with the pawn chain.  However, the point of the g2 B is to play against Black's Queenside.  White's K was the one that turned out to be vulnerable.
